page.title: List of productions directed by Konstantin Stanislavski

revision.comment: /* Productions at the Moscow Art Theatre */
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2016}} {{Use British English|date=August 2016}} {{Main article|Konstantin Stanislavski}} [[File:Stanislavski as Colonel Vershinin in Chekhov's The Three Sisters.jpg|thumb|right|[[Konstantin Stanislavski]] as Vershinin in [[Anton Chekhov]]'s ''[[Three Sisters (play)|Three Sisters]]''.]] This article offers a chronological '''list of productions directed by Konstantin Stanislavski'''. It does not include theatrical productions in which [[Konstantin Stanislavski|Stanislavski]] only acted.
Until he was thirty three, Stanislavski appeared only as an [[Amateur theatre|amateur]] onstage and as a [[Theatre director|director]], as a result of his family's discouragement.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 21, 24) and Carnicke (2000, 11). The prospect of becoming a professional actor was [[taboo]] for someone of Stanislavski's [[social class]]; actors had an even lower [[social status]] in Russia than in the rest of Europe, having only recently been [[Russian serfdom|serfs]] and the [[property]] of the [[nobility]].</ref> When he was twenty five, he helped to establish a Society of Art and Literature, which aimed to unite amateur and professional actors and artists.<ref>Magarshack (1950, 52, 55–56).</ref> His professional career began in 1896 when he co-founded the [[Moscow Art Theatre]] (MAT) with [[Vladimir Nemirovich-Danchenko]].<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 61–64).</ref> Later in his life, he created a series of studios whose aims were primarily [[Theatre pedagogy|pedagogical]] but which also presented public performances.<ref>Gauss (1999).</ref> This list of productions directed by Stanislavski includes amateur, professional, and studio productions.
When the sources disagree about the exact date of a production's [[Premiere|première]], that given in the most recent biography of Stanislavski—Jean Benedetti's ''Stanislavski: His Life and Art'' (1988, revised and expanded 1999)—is listed here, with the alternative date detailed in the footnotes. Prior to 14 February 1918, the [[Julian calendar]] was in use in Russia, after which the [[Gregorian calendar]] was introduced.<ref>In the 19th century, the difference between the two calendars was twelve days; in the 20th, 13 days; see Gauss (1999, 6).</ref> The details of productions staged before that change are given in both [[Old Style and New Style dates]].
==Productions at the Society of Art and Literature== [[File:Stanislavski Foma (1893).jpg|thumb|right|[[Konstantin Stanislavski|Stanislavski]] and his wife [[Maria Lilina|Lilina]] in his adaptation of [[Fyodor Dostoyevsky|Dostoyevsky's]] ''[[The Village of Stepanchikovo]]'' (''Foma'') for the Society of Art and Literature. Photograph taken in 1893.]] * 1891: '''''[[The Fruits of Enlightenment]]''''' by [[Leo Tolstoy]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|20 February|8 February}} at the German (Nemetsky) Club.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 385), Magarshack (1950, 78), and Worrall (1996, 27).</ref> Cast included [[Maria Lilina]], [[Alexander Sanin]], [[Alexander Artem]], [[Vasily Luzhsky]], Maria Samarova, and [[Vera Komissarzhevskaya]]; Stanislavski played Zvesdinstsev.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 42—43, 385), Magarshack (1950, 80), and Worrall (1996, 27).</ref> Reviewing the production, [[Vladimir Nemirovich-Danchenko]] wrote of Stanislavski's performance that "no one has ever seen such an exemplary performance on an [[Amateur theatre|amateur]] stage."<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 43), Magarshack (1950, 79), and Worrall (1996, 27).</ref> * 1891: '''''[[The Village of Stepanchikovo|Foma]]''''' by [[Fyodor Dostoyevsky]], adapted by Stanislavski from ''The Village of Stepanchikovo''. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|26 November|14 November}} at the German Club. Cast included Stanislavski as Colonel Rostanev and Maria Lilina as Nastenka.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 43, 231, 385) and Magarshack (1950, 80).</ref> * 1894: '''''The Governor''''' by [[Victor Diachenko]]. Cast included Stanislavski as George Dorci. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|19 February|7 February}}.<ref name=b385>Benedetti (1999a, 385).</ref> * 1894: '''''[[Light Without Heat]]''''' by [[Alexander Ostrovsky]] and N. Y. Solovyev. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|27 December|15 December}}. Cast included Stanislavski as Rabachev<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 385). The original Russian-language title of [[Alexander Ostrovsky|Ostrovsky]]'s play is ''Светит, да не греет''.</ref> and [[Maria Fyodorovna Andreyeva|Maria Andreyeva]] who made her stage debut as Olya Vasilkova.<ref name="mat_andreeva">[http://mxat.ru/history/persons/andreeva_m/ Maria Andreyeva]. Biography at the Moscow Art Theatre site</ref> * 1895: '''''[[Uriel Acosta#Gutzkow's Uriel Acosta|Uriel Acosta]]''''' by [[Karl Gutzkow]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|21 January|9 January}}. Cast included Stanislavski as Acosta.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 49, 385), Magarshack (1950, 86—90), and Worrall (1996, 29).</ref> * 1895: '''''[[Men Above the Law]]''''' by [[Aleksey Pisemsky]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|18 December|6 December}} at the [[Private Opera|Solodovnikov Theatre]]. Cast included Stanislavski as the elderly general, Prince Imshin.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 38, 385), Magarshack (1950, 100) and Worrall (1996, 27). Benedetti gives its opening as {{OldStyleDateNY|18 December|6 December}}, while Magarshack gives it as {{OldStyleDateNY|29 October|17 October}}. The title of [[Aleksey Pisemsky|Pisemsky's]] play has also been translated as ''A Law unto Themselves'' and ''Despots''.</ref> * 1896: '''''[[Othello]]''''' by [[William Shakespeare]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|31 January|19 January}} at the [[Private Opera|Solodovnikov Theatre]]. Cast included Stanislavski as [[Othello (Othello)|Othello]] and Khristofor Petrossyan as [[Iago]]. [[Vsevolod Meyerhold]] was greatly impressed by Stanislavski's performance, though Stanislavski was dissatisfied.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 52, 385), Magarshack (1950, 102, 107), and Worrall (1996, 29). Benedetti and Worrall give its opening as {{OldStyleDateNY|31 January|19 January}}, while Magarshack gives it as {{OldStyleDateNY|28 April|16 April}}.</ref> * 1896: '''''[[The Assumption of Hannele]]''''' by [[Gerhart Hauptmann]]. Cast included Anna Aleeva-Shteker as Hanna. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|14 April|2 April}} at the [[Private Opera|Solodovnikov Theatre]].<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 385) and Magarshack (1950, 102).</ref> * 1896: '''''[[The Bells (play)|The Polish Jew]]''''' by [[Erckmann-Chatrian]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|1 December|19 November}}.<ref>''The Polish Jew'' ({{lang-fr|Le Juif Polonais}}) by [[Erckmann-Chatrian]] is better known in English-speaking countries under the title ''[[The Bells (play)|The Bells]]'', a translation by [[Leopold Davis Lewis|Leopold Lewis]] that brought [[Henry Irving]] great success when he staged it in 1871; see Benedetti (1999a, 58).</ref> Cast included Stanislavski as Matthias.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 385) and Worrall (1996, 30).</ref> * 1896: '''''[[Without a Dowry]]''''' by [[Alexander Ostrovsky]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|31 December|19 December 1896}}.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 385) and Magarshack (1950, 117—118). The play's title is also translated as ''The Dowerless Bride'', ''The Girl without a Dowry'', and ''The Poor Bride''. Stanislavski's acting teacher, [[Glikeriya Fedotova]], had played the lead role, Larisa, in the play's première production in 1878.</ref> * 1897: '''''[[Much Ado About Nothing]]''''' by [[William Shakespeare]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|18 February|6 February}}. Cast included Stanislavski as Benedick.<ref name=b385/> * 1897: '''''[[Twelfth Night]]''''' by [[William Shakespeare]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|29 December|17 December}}. Cast included Stanislavski as [[Malvolio]].<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 66) and Worrall (1996, 102).</ref> * 1898: '''''[[The Sunken Bell]]''''' by [[Gerhart Hauptmann]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|8 February|27 January}}. Cast included Stanislavski as Heinrich.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 66) and Magarshack (1950, 133—135).</ref> This was the first production on which Stanislavski worked with the scenic designer [[Viktor Simov]].<ref>Magarshack (1950, 127—128, 131—133).</ref> [[Princess Elisabeth of Hesse and by Rhine (1864–1918)|Princess Elizaveta Fedorovna]] saw the production three times.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 66).</ref>
==Productions at the Moscow Art Theatre== [[File:Fyodor Ivanovich by A K Tolstoy.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Moscow Art Theatre]]'s production of ''[[Tsar Fyodor Ioannovich]]'' by [[Aleksey Konstantinovich Tolstoy|Alexei Tolstoy]]. Photograph taken during the company's [[Konstantin Stanislavski#MAT tour to the United States|tour to the USA]] in 1923.]] {{Main article|Moscow Art Theatre}} * 1898: '''''[[Tsar Fyodor Ioannovich]]''''' by [[Aleksey Konstantinovich Tolstoy|Alexei Tolstoy]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|26 October|14 October}}.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 83) and Magarshack (1950, 161—162, 176).</ref> Directed by Stanislavski and [[Alexander Sanin]].<ref>Worrall (1996, 101).</ref> Scenic design by [[Viktor Simov]].<ref>Braun (1982, 61—62) and Worrall (1996, 89—90).</ref> Cast included [[Vsevolod Meyerhold]] as Prince Vasili Shuysky, [[Olga Knipper]] as Princess Irina, [[Maria Roksanova]] as Princess Mstislavskaya,<ref name="mat_roksanova"/> [[Aleksandr Leonidovich Vishnevsky|Alexander Vishnevsky]] as Boris Godunov, Vasily Luzhsky as Prince Ivan Shuysky, [[Mikhail Darski]] as Prince Andrey Shuysky,<ref name="darski_mat">[http://www.mxat.ru/history/persons/darskiy/ Михаил Егорович Дарский] at the Moscow Art Theatre site</ref> [[Alexander Sanin]] as Lup-Kleshnin, [[Georgy Burdzhalov]] as Mikhaylo Golovin,<ref name="bur">[http://mxat.ru/history/persons/burdzhalov/ Georgy Burdzhalov]. The biography at the Moscow Art Theatre site </ref> [[Maria Samarova]] as Volokhova<ref name="mat_samarova">Radishcheva, O. [http://mxat.ru/history/persons/samarova/ Мария Александровна Самарова]. Biography at the Moscow Art Theatre site.</ref> and Alexander Artem as Kryukov; [[Ivan Moskvin]] initially played Fedor, followed by [[Vasily Kachalov]] and then Nikolai Khmelev.<ref>Worrall (1996, 90). While Worrall and Leach give [[Vsevolod Meyerhold]]'s role as Prince Vasili Shuyshy, Braun gives it as Prince Ivan Shuysky, with Worrall giving Vasily Luzhsky as the actor who played the latter role; see Braun (1995, 11), Leach (1989, 3), and Worrall (1996, 90).</ref> The [[Censorship in the Russian Empire|censor]] insisted on the removal of all religious characters from the production.<ref>Worrall (1996, 85).</ref> * 1898: '''''[[The Sunken Bell]]''''' by [[Gerhart Hauptmann]]. Revival of Stanislavski's Society of Art and Literature production from January the same year.<ref>Worrall (1996, 102—103).</ref> Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|31 October|19 October}}. Scenic design by [[Viktor Simov]]. Cast included Stanislavski as Heinrich, [[Ekaterina Munt]] as the First Elf,<ref name="munt_mat">[http://mxat.ru/history/persons/munt_e/ Екатерина Михайловна Мунт]. Biography at the Moscow Art Theatre site</ref> [[Margarita Savitskaya]] as Magda<ref name="sav_mat">[http://mxat.ru/history/persons/savitskaya_m/ Маргарита Георгиевна Савицкая]. Biography at the Moscow Art Theatre site by Inna Solovyova</ref> and Georgy Burdzhalov as the Wood Demon.<ref name="bur"/> Just over one week and 17 performances later, protests from the [[Russian Orthodox Church]] led to the production being banned on {{OldStyleDateNY|8 November|27 October}}, despite the particular translation used having been passed by the [[Censorship in the Russian Empire|censor]].<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 84), Braun (1982, 61), and Magarshack (1950, 161, 178).</ref> * 1898: '''''[[The Merchant of Venice]]''''' by [[William Shakespeare]]. The production was re-titled ''Shylock''.<ref name=w103>Worrall (1996, 103).</ref> Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|2 November|21 October}}.<ref>Benedetti (1999, 84).</ref> Scenic design by [[Viktor Simov]].<ref name=simov>Braun (1982, 61).</ref> Cast included Mikhail Darski as [[Shylock]],<ref name="darski_mat"/> [[Aleksandr Leonidovich Vishnevsky|Alexander Vishnevsky]] as [[Antonio (The Merchant of Venice)|Antonio]], [[Vsevolod Meyerhold]] as the Prince of Aragon,<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 70—71) and (1999b, 259), Braun (1995, 11), and Worrall (1996, 104).</ref> Georgy Burdzhalov as Launcelot Gobbo.<ref name="bur"/> This production was the first in Russia to include the fifth act of the play, after the trial scene and humiliation of Shylock, when the intrigue of Portia's ring and cross-dressing is revealed and resolved.<ref name=w103/> The portrayal of Shylock prompted accusations in the press of [[anti-Semitism]] because a Jewish accent was considered inappropriate for a [[Tragic hero|tragic role]].<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 84) and Worrall (1996, 104).</ref> Though Stanislavski had planned to alternate the role with Darski, he decided against it for fear of exacerbating the hostility of the press.<ref name="Benedetti 1999a 84">Benedetti (1999a, 84)</ref> It was played for only ten performances.<ref>Magarshack (1950, 161).</ref> * 1898: '''''[[Men Above the Law]]''''' by [[Aleksey Pisemsky]].<ref>The title of [[Aleksey Pisemsky|Pisemsky]]'s play has also been translated as ''A Law unto Themselves'' and as ''Despots''.</ref> Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|16 November|4 November}}.<ref name="Benedetti 1999a 84"/> Scenic design by [[Viktor Simov]].<ref name=simov/> Cast included Stanislavski as Platon Imshin, Alexander Artyom as Devochkin, Ivan Moskvin as [[podyachy]], Vasily Luzhsky as Sergey Imshin,<ref name="roshal">Roshal, A. A. [http://az.lib.ru/p/pisemskij_a/text_0420.shtml Commentaries to Самоуправцы].The Works of A.Pisemsky in 9 volumes. Vol.9. Ogonyok Library / Pravda Publishers.1959</ref> [[Evgeniya Rayevskaya]] as Princess Natalya<ref name="rayevskaya_mat">[http://mxat.ru/history/persons/raevskaya_e/ Евгения Михайловна Раевская] at the Moscow Art Theatre</ref> and Georgy Burdzhalov as Kadushkin.<ref name="bur"/> It played for only nine performances.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 386), Magarshack (1950, 161) and Worrall (1996, 104).</ref> [[File:Constantin Stanislavski in Goldoni's Locandiera in 1898.jpg|thumb|right|[[Konstantin Stanislavski|Stanislavski]] as Ripafratta in his [[Moscow Art Theatre]] production of [[Carlo Goldoni]]'s comedy ''[[The Mistress of the Inn]]''.]] * 1898: '''''[[The Mistress of the Inn]]''''' by [[Carlo Goldoni]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|14 December|2 December}}.<ref name=b85>Benedetti (1999a, 85).</ref> Scenic design by [[Viktor Simov]].<ref name=simov/> Cast included Stanislavski as Ripafratta, [[Vsevolod Meyerhold]] as the Marquis of Forlipopoli, and Sergey Tarasov as Ripafratta's servant.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 85), Braun (1995, 11), Worrall (1996, 106). Sergey Tarasov was a member of the company between 1898 and 1899.</ref> A special performance for factory workers on {{OldStyleDateNY|22 January|10 January}} 1899 provoked a summons by the Chief of Police, [[Dmitri Feodorovich Trepov|Dmitri Trepov]], for failing to seek the approval of the [[Censorship in the Russian Empire|censor]] who oversaw productions for working-class audiences; as a result, the company abandoned its original name as the "Moscow Public-Accessible Theatre" and its aim to provide an "open" theatre, settling instead on [[Anton Chekhov]]'s suggestion, the "[[Moscow Art Theatre]]."<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 87) and Braun (1982, 60).</ref> * 1898: '''''[[The Seagull]]''''' by [[Anton Chekhov]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|29 December|17 December}}.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 386), Braun (1982, 64), and Magarshack (1950, 162, 179), and Worrall (1996, 106).</ref> Directed by Stanislavski and [[Vladimir Nemirovich-Danchenko]].<ref>Magarshack (1950, 162). Vasily Luzhsky also led two of the production's rehearsals.</ref> Cast included Stanislavski as Trigorin and [[Vsevolod Meyerhold]] as Konstantin, [[Olga Knipper]] as Arkadnia, Maria Lilina as Masha, Maria Roksanova as Nina, Yevgeniya Raevskaya as Polina, [[Ioasaf Tikhomirov]] as Medvedenko, Vasily Luzhsky as Sorin, [[Aleksandr Leonidovich Vishnevsky|Alexander Vishnevsky]] as Dorn, and Alexander Artem as Shamrayev.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 85—87, 386) Gottlieb (2005, lxxxi—lxxxv, 244), Magarshack (1950, 178—179), and Senelick (2013, vii).</ref> The production ran for 57 performances in the 1898—99 season, 13 in the next, and 9 in the 1900—01 season.<ref>Magarshack (1950, 182).</ref> Chekhov disliked Roksanova's performance so intensely that he demanded that she should never be allowed to act in his plays again.<ref>Magarshack (1950, 191).</ref> For more information on this production, see [[Moscow Art Theatre production of The Seagull|the article on the MAT production of ''The Seagull'']]. * 1899: '''''[[Hedda Gabler]]''''' by [[Henrik Ibsen]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|3 March|19 February}}. Scenic design by [[Viktor Simov]]. Cast included Stanislavski as Løvborg, Maria Samarova as Aunt Julia<ref name="mat_samarova"/> and [[Maria Fyodorovna Andreyeva|Maria Andreyeva]] as Hedda.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 87, 90—91, 386), Braun (1982, 61), Innes (2000, 112), and Worrall (1996, 110—111).</ref> It played for only eleven performances.<ref>Magarshack (1950, 161, 188) and Worrall (1996, 111).</ref> Reflecting on the production years later, the critic Nikolai Efros regarded Stanislavski's performance as the best of an Ibsen character he had seen.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 90—91), Magarshack (1950, 188), Worrall (1996, 111).</ref> [[File:Meyerhold ivan4.jpg|thumb|right|[[Vsevolod Meyerhold]] as Tsar Ivan in [[Konstantin Stanislavski|Stanislavski]]'s production of ''[[The Death of Ivan the Terrible]]'' at the [[Moscow Art Theatre]].]] * 1899: '''''[[The Death of Ivan the Terrible]]''''' by [[Aleksey Konstantinovich Tolstoy|Alexei Tolstoy]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|11 October|29 September}}. Scenic design by [[Viktor Simov]]. Cast included [[Aleksandr Leonidovich Vishnevsky|Alexander Vishnevsky]] as Boris Godunov, Margarita Savitskaya as Tsaritsa Maria<ref name="sav_mat"/> and Anna Aleeva-Shteker as Maria Godunov. Stanislavski initially played Ivan, though [[Vsevolod Meyerhold]] took over the part after a few performances when Stanislavski became unwell.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 95, 386), Braun (1982, 61) and (1995, 11), Magarshack (1950, 188—189), and Worrall (1996, 112). Benedetti gives the opening performance as {{OldStyleDateNY|11 October|29 September}}, while Magarshack gives {{OldStyleDateNY|10 November|29 October}}.</ref> * 1899: '''''[[Twelfth Night]]''''' by [[William Shakespeare]]. Revival of Stanislavski's Society of Art and Literature production from two years earlier.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 92).</ref> Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|15 October|3 October}}.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 98, 386). Benedetti gives the opening performance as {{OldStyleDateNY|15 October|3 October}}, while Worrall gives {{OldStyleDateNY|24 October|12 October}}; see Worrall (1996, 114).</ref> Scenic design by [[Viktor Simov]].<ref name=simov/> In this production, [[Vsevolod Meyerhold]] played [[Malvolio]], [[Olga Knipper]] played [[Viola (Twelfth Night)|Viola]], [[Maria Fyodorovna Andreyeva|Maria Andreyeva]] played [[Olivia (Twelfth Night)|Olivia]], and Vasily Luzhsky played [[Sir Toby Belch|Sir Toby]].<ref>Worrall (1996, 114).</ref> * 1899: '''''[[Drayman Henschel]]''''' by [[Gerhart Hauptmann]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|17 October|5 October}}. Scenic design by [[Viktor Simov]]. Cast included both Anna Aleeva-Shteker and Maria Roksanova as Hanna,<ref>Benedetti (1991, 51) and (1999a, 98, 386), Braun (1982, 61), Magarshack (1950, 188), and Worrall (1996, 114)</ref> as well as Ekaterina Munt as Franziska Wermelskirch.<ref name="munt_mat"/> The play's title has also been translated as ''The Driver Henschel''. Anna Alekseieva-Shteker was Stanislavski's sister, who used the [[stage name]] of Anna Aleeva-Shteker; see Benedetti (1991, 51) and the [[:ru:Алеева-Штекер, Анна Сергеевна|article on her]] on the Russian-language Wikipedia.</ref> [[File:Uncle Vanya act III Moscow Art Theatre.jpg|thumb|Armed with a [[Chekhov's gun|revolver]], Vanya ([[Aleksandr Leonidovich Vishnevsky|Alexander Vishnevsky]]) confronts Professor Serebriakov (Vasily Luzhsky) at the end of act three of [[Anton Chekhov]]'s ''[[Uncle Vanya]]'' (1899) at the [[Moscow Art Theatre]].]] * 1899: '''''[[Uncle Vanya]]''''' by [[Anton Chekhov]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|7 November|26 October}}. Scenic design by [[Viktor Simov]]. Cast included [[Aleksandr Leonidovich Vishnevsky|Alexander Vishnevsky]] as Vanya, Vasily Luzhsky as Professor Serebriakov, [[Olga Knipper]] as Yeliena, Maria Lilina as Sonia, Alexander Artem as Telyeghin, Maria Samarova as Marina, and Stanislavski as Astrov.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 94), Braun (1982, 61), Gottlieb (2005, lxxxi—lxxxv), Magarshack (1950, 190—192), and Worrall (1996, 115–116).</ref> The [[Grand Duke Sergei Alexandrovich of Russia|Grand Duke Sergey Alexandrovich]] and his wife, [[Princess Elisabeth of Hesse and by Rhine (1864–1918)|Princess Elizaveta Fedorovna]], along with [[Konstantin Pobedonostsev]] (the reactionary [[Ober-Procurator]] of the [[Most Holy Synod]]), saw the tenth performance of the play and were greatly impressed.<ref name=m194>Magarshack (1950, 194).</ref> [[Leo Tolstoy]] saw the production on {{OldStyleDateNY|6 February|24 January}} 1900.<ref name=m194/> * 1899: '''''Lonely People''''' by [[Gerhart Hauptmann]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|28 December|16 December}}. Scenic design by [[Viktor Simov]]. [[Vsevolod Meyerhold]] played Johannes Vockerat until he left the company, after which [[Vasily Kachalov]] took over the role. Cast included also Maria Samarova as Frau Vockerat.<ref name="mat_samarova"/> This production was the play's première in Russia.<ref>Braun (1995, 11) and Worrall (1996, 118—119).</ref> * 1900: '''''[[The Snow Maiden (play)|Snow Maiden]]''''' by [[Alexander Ostrovsky]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|7 October|24 September}}. Scenic design by [[Viktor Simov]]. Cast included [[Vasily Kachalov]] as Tsar Berendey (his first performance at the MAT), Ekaterina Munt as the Snow Maiden, Anna Aleeva-Shteker as Elena the Fair, Maria Samarova as Bobylikha,<ref name="mat_samarova"/> Maria Roksanova as Kupava,<ref name="mat_roksanova">[http://mxat.ru/history/persons/roksanova/ Maria Roksanova]'s biography at the Moscow Art Theatre site</ref> Margarita Savitskaya as the Sping,<ref name="sav_mat"/> [[Olga Knipper]], [[Ivan Moskvin]], [[Aleksandr Leonidovich Vishnevsky|Alexander Vishnevsky]], [[Vladimir Gribunin]], and . When the MAT production opened, four other productions of Ostrovsky's play also were playing in Moscow.<ref>Benedetti (1991, 364) and Worrall (1996, 121—122). Ekaterina Munt was [[Vsevolod Meyerhold]]'s sister-in-law who had also studied under [[Vladimir Nemirovich-Danchenko]] at the [[Russian Academy of Theatre Arts|Philharmonic school]].</ref> * 1900: '''''[[An Enemy of the People]]''''' by [[Henrik Ibsen]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|6 November|24 October}}. Scenic design by [[Viktor Simov]]. Cast included Stanislavski as Dr Stockmann and [[Aleksandr Leonidovich Vishnevsky|Alexander Vishnevsky]] as Hovstad.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 167, 386).</ref> * 1901: '''''[[Three Sisters (play)|Three Sisters]]''''' by [[Anton Chekhov]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|13 February|31 January}}. Scenic design by [[Viktor Simov]]. Cast included Stanislavski as Vershinin, [[Olga Knipper]] as Masha, Maria Andreyeva as Irina,<ref name="mat_andreeva"/> [[Vsevolod Meyerhold]] as Tusenback, Maria Samarova as Anfisa<ref name="mat_samarova"/> and Alexander Vishnevsky as Kulygin. This became the most popular of the MAT's productions of Chekhov's plays, remaining part of the company's repertoire for the next 18 years.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 386), Braun (1995, 12), Gottlieb (2005, 245), and Worrall (1996, 126—127). The final performance of this production of ''[[Three Sisters (play)|Three Sisters]]'' took place on 4 May 1919. [[Vladimir Nemirovich-Danchenko]] directed a new production in 1940.</ref> * 1901: '''''[[The Wild Duck]]''''' by [[Henrik Ibsen]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|2 October|19 September}}. Directed by Stanislavski and [[Alexander Sanin]]. Scenic design by [[Viktor Simov]]. The production played for no more than 16 performances.<ref>Braun (1982, 61), Magarshack (1950, 230), and Worrall (1996, 128).</ref> * 1901: '''''Michael Kramer''''' by [[Gerhart Hauptmann]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|9 November|27 October}}. Scenic design by [[Viktor Simov]]. Cast included [[Maria Fyodorovna Andreyeva|Maria Andreyeva]] as Michaelina Kramer, Stanislavski as Michael Kramer, and [[Ivan Moskvin]] as his son, Arnold. It played for twenty-six performances.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 386), Braun (1982, 61), Senelick (2013, 143), Worrall (1996, 128—129).</ref> * 1901—2: '''''In Dreams''''' by [[Vladimir Nemirovich-Danchenko]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateDY|3 January|1902|21 December 1901}}. Scenic design by [[Viktor Simov]]. Cast included [[Maria Fyodorovna Andreyeva|Maria Andreyeva]] as Vera Kirillovna, Maria Samarova as Zankovskaya,<ref name="mat_samarova"/> Ekaterina Munt as m-lle Solntseva<ref name="munt_mat"/> and Stanislavski as Kostromskoy. It played for thirty-eight performances. This was the last of the MAT's productions presented at the [[Moscow Hermitage Garden|Hermitage Theatre on Carriage Row]].<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 386), Braun (1982, 61), Senelick (2013, 144), and Worrall (1996, 130—131).</ref> * 1902: '''''[[The Philistines]]''''' by [[Maxim Gorky]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|8 April|26 March}} in St Petersburg, while the MAT were on tour. Scenic design by [[Viktor Simov]]. Cast included Nikolai Baranov as Teterev, Vasily Luzhsky as Bessemenov, [[Elena Muratova (actress)|Elena Muratova]] as Akulina Ivanovna<ref name="muratova_mat">Radishcheva, O. (О. Радищева) [http://mxat.ru/history/persons/muratova/ Елена Павловна Муратова]. Biography at the Moscow Art Theatre site. </ref> and [[Vsevolod Meyerhold]] as Peter (until he left the company after the St Petersburg performances). Its Moscow première inaugurated the MAT's new building (in the renovated Lianozov Theatre, also known as the Omon Theatre, on Chamberlain Lane, [[Tverskoy District]]) on {{OldStyleDateNY|6 November|25 October}}. The production played for a total of twenty-seven performances.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 120—121, 126), Braun (1982, 61), (1988, xvi), and (1995, 13, 16), Marsh (1993, 14), Magarshack (1950, 230—231), Senelick (2013, 151, 186), and Worrall (1996, 72—78, 131). The title of ''The Philistines'' has also been translated as ''Small People'', ''The Merchant Class'', ''The Petty-Bourgeois'', and ''The Artisans''. It premièred in St Petersburg in early 1902 as part of the MAT's tour.</ref> * 1902: '''''[[The Power of Darkness]]''''' by [[Leo Tolstoy]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|18 November|5 November}}. Scenic design by [[Viktor Simov]]. Cast included Stanislavski as Mitrich, though he only appeared in three performances before passing on the role to another actor,<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 126–127, 386), Magarshack (1950, 233, 238–239), and Worrall (1996, 132—133). Benedetti and Worrall give the opening performance as {{OldStyleDateNY|18 November|5 November}}, while Magarshack gives {{OldStyleDateNY|2 December|19 November}}.</ref> and [[Sophia Khalyutina]] as Anyutka.<ref name="mat">[http://mxat.ru/history/persons/halyutina/ Софья Васильевна Халютина]. Biography at the Moscow Art Theatr site.</ref> [[File:The Lower Depths by Gorky.jpg|thumb|[[Konstantin Stanislavski|Stanislavski]] as Satin (seated, centre) in the [[Moscow Art Theatre]] production of [[Maxim Gorky]]'s ''[[The Lower Depths]]''.]] * 1902: '''''[[The Lower Depths]]''''' by [[Maxim Gorky]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|31 December|18 December}}. Directed by Stanislavski and [[Vladimir Nemirovich-Danchenko]]. Scenic design by [[Viktor Simov]]. Cast included [[Georgy Burdzhalov]] as Kostyliov, Elena Muratova as Vassilissa, Maria Andreyeva as Natasha, [[Vladimir Gribunin]] as Medvediev, Aleksei Kharlamov as Vassily Pepel, [[Alexander Zagarov]] as Kleshch, Margarita Savitskaya as Anna, [[Olga Knipper]] as Nastya, Maria Samarova as Kvashnia, Vasily Luzhsky as Bubnov, [[Vasili Kachalov]] as the Baron, Mikhail Gromov as the Actor, [[Ivan Moskvin]] as Luka, [[Alexander Adashev]] as Alyoshka, [[Aleksandr Leonidovich Vishnevsky|Alexander Vishnevsky]] as Tatar, and Nikolai Baranov as Krivoy Zob; Stanislavski played Satin for the first five performances, after which [[Serafim Sudbinin]] took over. Gorky saw the production nearly a year later, on {{OldStyleDateNY|18 October|5 October}} 1903.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 127, 130, 386), Braun (1988, xvii-xviii), Magarshack (1950, 244), and Worrall (1996, 134, 136—137).</ref> [[File:Stanislavski as Gaiev in Chekhov's The Cherry Orchard.jpg|thumb|right|[[Konstantin Stanislavski|Stanislavski]] as Gaev in the [[Moscow Art Theatre]] production of [[Anton Chekhov]]'s ''[[The Cherry Orchard]]''.]] * 1904: '''''[[The Cherry Orchard]]''''' by [[Anton Chekhov]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|30 January|17 January}}. Directed by Stanislavski and [[Vladimir Nemirovich-Danchenko]]. Scenic design by [[Viktor Simov]]. Cast included [[Olga Knipper]] as Madame Ranyevskaya, Maria Lilina as Anya, [[Maria Fyodorovna Andreyeva|Maria Andreyeva]] as Varya, Stanislavski as Gaev, [[Leonid Leonidov]] as Lopakhin, [[Vasili Kachalov]] as Trofimov, Elena Muratova as Charlotta,<ref name="muratova_mat"/> [[Ivan Moskvin]] as Yepihodov, Sofia Khaliutina as Dunyasha,<ref name="mat"/> Alexander Artem as Firs, [[Nikolai Alexandrov (actor)|Nikolai Alexandrov]] as Yasha, Mikhail Gromov as a passer-by, and Alexander Zagarov as the stationmaster. Chekhov's last appearance at the MAT, before his death on {{OldStyleDateNY|15 July|2 July}}, was to see the first public performance of this production, which coincided with his birthday.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 386), Gottlieb (2005, lxxxi—lxxxv, 247), and Worrall (1996, 152, 159, 212). Worrall describes the première as Chekhov's [[Name day#Russia|name day]], which in Russia is usually distinct from a birthday; he also lists Elena Muratova as "M. V. Muratova"; see Worrall (1996, 159—160).</ref> * 1904: '''''[[The Blind]]'', ''[[Intruder (play)|Intruder]]'', and ''[[Interior (play)|Interior]]''''' by [[Maurice Maeterlinck]]. Scenic design by [[Viktor Simov]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|15 October|2 October}}. * 1904—5: '''[[Anton Chekhov]] evening.''' Opened on {{OldStyleDateDY|3 January|1905|21 December 1904}}. * 1905: '''''[[Ghosts (play)|Ghosts]]''''' by [[Henrik Ibsen]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|13 April|31 March}}. Directed by Stanislavski and Nemirovich.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 267).</ref> Scenic design by [[Viktor Simov]]. Cast included Margarita Savitskaya as Mrs Alving, [[Ivan Moskvin]] as Osvald, and [[Vasili Kachalov]] as Manders.<ref>Marker and Marker (1989, 109) and Worrall (1996, 168).</ref> * 1905: '''''[[Children of the Sun (play)|Children of the Sun]]''''' by [[Maxim Gorky]]. Scenic design by [[Viktor Simov]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|6 November|24 October}}. * 1906: '''''[[Woe from Wit]]''''' by [[Aleksandr Griboyedov]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|9 October|26 September}}.<ref name="Benedetti 1999a 387">Benedetti (1999a, 387).</ref> Scenic design by [[Viktor Simov]]. Cast included Stanislavski as Pavel Afanasyevich Famusov, [[Vasili Kachalov]] as Chatski, and [[Aleksandr Leonidovich Vishnevsky|Alexander Vishnevsky]] as Count Tugoukhovsky. Both Stanislavski and Nemirovich directed; Benedetti suggests that "Stanislavski, however, would appear to have exerted the dominant influence" whereas Worrall claims that "most of the work was done by Nemirovich, Stanislavski merely introducing minor corrections and additions to Act Three."<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 171) and Worrall (1996, 170–171).</ref> Benedetti and Worrall also disagree as to whether the text was in [[prose]] or [[Verse (poetry)|verse]].<ref>Benedetti describes the excited response of Aleksandr Lensky, [[Maria Yermolova]] and [[Glikeriya Fedotova]] "when the inexorable flow of the verse was broken up by the use of pauses in Act Three", whereas Worrall describes [[Vsevolod Meyerhold]]'s sardonic response to [[Vladimir Nemirovich-Danchenko|Nemirovich's]] choice of a [[prose]] text; see Benedetti (1999a, 171) and Worrall (1996, 171).</ref> The MAT revived the production in 1914 and 1925.<ref>Worrall (1996, 170).</ref> * 1907: '''''The Drama of Life''''' by [[Knut Hamsun]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|21 February|8 February}}. Cast included Stanislavski as Kareno.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 174, 387) and Magarshack (1950, 287–289).</ref> Directed by Stanislavski with the assistance of [[Leopold Sulerzhitsky|Sulerzhitsky]].<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 172–174) and Magarshack (1950, 285–288).</ref> Music by Ilya Satz.<ref>Magarshack (1950, 289).</ref> * 1907: '''''[[The Life of Man]]''''' by [[Leonid Andreyev]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|25 December|12 December}}.<ref name="Benedetti 1999a 387"/> Cast included [[Leonid Leonidov]] as Man<ref>Magarshack (1950, 290).</ref> and [[Ilya Uralov]] as Someone in Grey.<ref name="mat_uralov">[http://mxat.ru/history/persons/uralov/ Илья Матвеевич Уралов]. Biography at the Moscow Art Theatre site</ref> [[File:The Blue Bird 1908 group trim.jpg|thumb|right|[[Konstantin Stanislavski|Stanislavski]]'s production of [[Maurice Maeterlinck]]'s ''[[The Blue Bird (play)|The Blue Bird]]'' in 1908.]] * 1908: '''''[[The Blue Bird (play)|The Blue Bird]]''''' by [[Maurice Maeterlinck]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|13 October|30 September}}. Cast included [[Alisa Koonen]] as Mytyl<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 249).</ref> and Sofia Khalyutina as Tiltil.<ref name="mat"/> * 1908: '''''[[The Government Inspector]]''''' by [[Nikolai Gogol]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|31 December|18 December}}.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 387) and Magarshack (1950, 294).</ref> Cast included Ilya Uralov as the Mayor.<ref name="mat_uralov"/> * 1909: '''''[[A Month in the Country (play)|A Month in the Country]]''''' by [[Ivan Turgenev]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|22 December|9 December}}.<ref>Benedetti (199a, 387) and Magarshack (1950, 309).</ref> Directed by Stanislavski and [[Ivan Moskvin]].<ref>Worrall (1996, 192).</ref> Cast included Stanislavski as Rakitin, alternating with [[Vasili Kachalov]], [[Olga Knipper]] as Natalya, [[Richard Boleslavsky]] as Belyaev, [[Nikolai Massalitinov]] as Islayev, Maria Samarova as Anna, [[Lydia Koreneva]] as Verochka, Elena Muratova as Lizaveta, Nikolai Zvantsev as Schaaf, Ilya Uralov as Bolshintsov, [[Vladimir Gribunin]] as Shpigelsky, I. V. Lazaryev as Matvei, and Lyubov Dmitrevskaya as Katya.<ref>Carnicke (1998, 36), Benedetti (1999a, 191, 212), and Worrall (1996, 194).</ref> Scenic design by [[Mstislav Dobuzhinsky]].<ref>Magarshack (1950, 309) and Worrall (1996, 189).</ref> This was the first production in which Stanislavski made use of his emerging [[Stanislavski's system|'system']], much to the general distress of the actors, and Knipper in particular.<ref>Worral (1996, 185).</ref> * 1910: '''''[[Enough Stupidity in Every Wise Man]]''''' by [[Alexander Ostrovsky]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|24 March|11 March}}.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 387). Magarshack gives its first performance as {{OldStyleDateNY|16 March|1910|3 March}} (1950, 312).</ref> Cast included Stanislavski as General Krutitski.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 212, 387).</ref> * 1911: '''''[[The Living Corpse]]''''' by [[Leo Tolstoy]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|6 October|23 September}}. Principally directed by Nemirovich.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 207).</ref> Cast included [[Alisa Koonen]] as Masha, [[Alexey Stakhovich]] as Prince Abrezkov<ref name="mxat">[http://mxat.ru/history/persons/stakhovich/ Biography of Stakhovich] at the Moscow Art Theatre site</ref> and [[Yevgeny Vakhtangov]] as the Gypsy.<ref>Vakhtangov (1982, 270) and Worrall (1996, 64).</ref> * 1911—12: '''''[[Hamlet]]''''' by [[William Shakespeare]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateDY|5 January|1912|23 December 1911}}. Cast included [[Vasili Kachalov]] as [[Prince Hamlet|Hamlet]], Nikolai Massalitinov as [[King Claudius|Claudius]], [[Olga Knipper]] as [[Gertrude (Hamlet)|Gertrude]], [[Olga Gzovskaya]] as [[Ophelia (character)|Ophelia]], and [[Yevgeny Vakhtangov]] as the actor-queen.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 199) and Vakhtangov (1982, 270).</ref> See [[Moscow Art Theatre production of Hamlet|the article on the MAT's production of ''Hamlet'']]. * 1912: '''''[[A Provincial Lady]]''''' by [[Ivan Turgenev]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|18 March|5 March}} as part of a triple bill of plays by Turgenev. Cast included Stanislavski as Count Liubin.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 213, 224).</ref> Scenic design by [[Mstislav Dobuzhinsky]].<ref>Worrall (1996, 223).</ref> [[File:Argan in The Imaginary Invalid in 1913.jpg|thumb|right|[[Konstantin Stanislavski|Stanislavski]] as Argan in [[Molière]]'s ''[[The Imaginary Invalid]]''.]] * 1913: '''''[[The Imaginary Invalid]]''''' by [[Molière]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|9 April|27 March}}.<ref name=b217>Benedetti (1999a, 217).</ref> Cast included Stanislavski as Argan and his Maria Lilina as Toinette.<ref name=b217/> Scenic design by [[Alexandre Benois]].<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 214).</ref> Rehearsals conducted at the First Studio as a demonstration of [[Stanislavski's 'system']].<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 211).</ref> * 1914: '''''[[The Mistress of the Inn]]''''' by [[Carlo Goldoni]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|16 February|3 February}} after 112 rehearsals.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 218).</ref> Cast included Stanislavski as Count Ripafratta. Scenic design by [[Alexandre Benois]].<ref name=b217/> The production was conceived as a showcase for [[Olga Gzovskaya]].<ref name=b217/> * 1915: '''''[[A Feast in Time of Plague]]'' and ''[[Mozart and Salieri (play)|Mozart and Salieri]]''''' by [[Alexander Pushkin]]. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|8 April|26 March}}. Cast included Stanislavski as Salieri.<ref name="Benedetti 1999a 387"/> Scenic design by [[Alexandre Benois]].<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 227).</ref> * 1916: '''''[[The Green Ring]]''''' by [[Zinaida Gippius]], performed by the Second Studio. Directed by [[Vakhtang Mchedelov]], with final rehearsals taken by Stanislavski. Opened on {{OldStyleDateNY|7 December|24 November}}.<ref>Gauss (1999, 131).</ref> Cast included [[Alexey Stakhovich]] as Uncle Mika and [[Alla Tarasova]] as Finochka.<ref name="arz">Arzamastseva, Irina [http://www.nlobooks.ru/node/6584#_ftn3 The Three Souls of a Russian Provincial Gymnasium Girl] // Три души провинциальной гимназистки (пьеса З.Н. Гиппиус «Зеленое кольцо»).</ref> * 1917—18: '''''[[Twelfth Night]]''''' by [[William Shakespeare]], in a translation by [[Pyotr Veinberg]], performed by the First Studio.<ref>Gauss (1999, 128) and Magarshack (1950, 350).</ref> Directed by [[Boris Sushkevich]], under the supervision of Stanislavski.<ref>Gauss (1999, 128).</ref> Opened on {{OldStyleDateDY|7 January|1918|25 December 1917}}.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 261, 386). Gauss gives its opening as {{OldStyleDateNY|4 December|21 November}} 1917; see Gauss (1999, 128).</ref> Scenic design by [[André Andrejew]], with music by N. N. Rakhmanov.<ref>Gauss (1999, 128). Gauss gives [[André Andrejew]]'s name in the form A. V. Andreev.</ref> After seeing a work-in-progress showing, Stanislavski took over the direction and "rebuilt the production stone by stone".<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 260).</ref> Recommending the production to [[Vladimir Lenin]], [[Anatoly Lunacharsky]] praised it as the best in Moscow.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 261).</ref> * 1920: '''''[[Cain (play)|Cain]]''''' by [[George Gordon Byron, 6th Baron Byron|Byron]]. Opened on 4 April. Cast included [[Leonid Leonidov]] as Cain and Alexander Shakhalov as Lucifer.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 261, 264). Alexander Shakhalov was a member of the company between 1916 and 1924.</ref> Scenic design by [[Nikolay Andreyev]].<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 265) and Rudnitsky (1988, 88).</ref> * 1921: '''''[[The Government Inspector]]''''' by [[Nikolai Gogol]]. Opened on 2 October.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 388); Magarshack gives the opening date as 8 October (1950, 355).</ref> Cast included [[Michael Chekhov]] as Khlestakov.<ref>Worrall (1996, 180).</ref> * 1926: '''''[[An Ardent Heart]]''''' by [[Alexander Ostrovsky]]. Opened on 23 January.<ref>Magarshack (1950, 369). The title of [[Alexander Ostrovsky|Ostrovsky]]'s play has also been translated as ''A Burning Heart''.</ref> * 1926: '''''Nicholas I and the Decembrists''''' by [[Aleksandr Kugel]]. Opened on 18 May. Cast included [[Vasily Kachalov]] as [[Nicholas I of Russia|Nicholas I]], [[Leonid Leonidov]] as a protagonist and [[Nikolai Podgorny (actor)|Nikolai Podgorny]] as [[Pavel Pestel]].<ref>[http://mxat.ru/history/persons/merezhkovskiy/ Dmitry Merezhkovsky] at the Moscow Art Theatre site</ref> * 1926: '''''Merchants of Glory''''' by [[Marcel Pagnol]] and Paul Nivoix. Opened on 15 June. * 1926: '''''[[The Days of the Turbins]]''''' by [[Mikhail Bulgakov]] (adapted from his novel ''[[The White Guard]]''). Opened on 5 October. Cast included [[Nikolai Khmelyov]] as Alexey Turbin<ref>{{cite web | author = | date = | url = http://mxat.ru/history/persons/hmelev_np/|title = Nikolai Khmelyov's Biography | publisher = mxat.ru (Moscow Art Theatre site)| accessdate = 1 March 2016}}</ref> and [[Boris Dobronravov]] as Myshlayevsky.<ref>[http://mxat.ru/history/persons/dobronravov/ Boris Dobronravov]. Biography at the Moscow Art Theatre site</ref> * 1927: '''''[[The Marriage of Figaro (play)|The Marriage of Figaro]]''''' by [[Pierre Beaumarchais]]. Opened 28 April. Scenic design by [[Aleksandr Golovin (artist)|Aleksandr Golovin]].<ref>Benedetti (1999b, 274) and Magarshack (1950, 370).</ref> * 1927: '''''The Gérard Sisters''''' (''[[The Two Orphans (play)|The Two Orphans]]'') by [[Adolphe d'Ennery]] and [[Eugène Cormon]]. Opened on 29 October. [[File:Armoured Train 14-69 Moscow 1927.jpg|thumb|right|[[Konstantin Stanislavski|Stanislavski]]'s production of ''[[Armoured Train 14-69]]'' (1927) by [[Vsevolod Ivanov]].]] * 1927: '''''[[Armoured Train 14-69]]''''' by [[Vsevolod Ivanov]]. Opened 8 November. Cast included [[Olga Knipper]] as Nadezhda Lvovna and [[Vasili Kachalov]] as Vershinin.<ref>Solovyova (1999, 347) and Leach (2004, 42).</ref> Scenic design by [[Viktor Simov]].<ref>Leach (2004, 42).</ref> * 1928: '''''[[Untilovsk]]''''' by [[Leonid Leonov]]. Opened on 17 February. * 1928: '''''[[The Embezzlers]]''''' by [[Valentin Kataev]]. Opened on 20 April. Cast included [[Mikhail Tarkhanov (actor)|Mikhail Tarkhanov]] as Prokhorov, Vasily Toporkov as Vanechka and [[Nikolai Batalov]] as Nikita.<ref>L. Skorino. [http://www.lib.ru/PROZA/KATAEW/rastratchiki.txt Commentaries to Растратчики]. The Collected Works by V.P. Katayev. Khudozhestvennaya Literatura. Volume 3. 1969</ref> * 1930: '''''[[Othello]]''''' by [[William Shakespeare]]. Opened 14 March. Cast included [[Leonid Leonidov]] as Othello.<ref>Worrall (1996, 212).</ref> * 1932: '''''[[Dead Souls]]''''' by [[Nikolai Gogol]], adapted by [[Mikhail Bulgakov]]. Opened on 28 November. Scenic design by [[Viktor Simov]].<ref>Magarshack (1950, 381–382).</ref> * 1933: '''''[[Talents and Admirers]]''''' by [[Alexander Ostrovsky]]. Opened on 14 June.<ref>Magarshack (1950, 386).</ref> * 1933: '''''[[The Barber of Seville]]''''' by [[Gioachino Rossini]]. Opened on 26 October. * 1935: '''''[[Carmen]]''''' by [[Georges Bizet]]. Opened on 4 April. * 1936: '''''[[The Cabal of Hypocrites|Molière]]''''' (also known as ''The Cabal of Hypocrites'') by [[Mikhail Bulgakov]]. Opened on 11 February. * 1936: '''''[[Don Pasquale]]''''' by [[Gaetano Donizetti]]. Opened on 22 May.
==Opera Studio productions== * 1921: '''[[Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov]] evening'''. Opened on 9 June.<ref>Stanislavski and Rumyantsev (1998, 40–41) and Benedetti (1999a, 257).</ref> Presented at the [[Moscow Art Theatre|MAT]].<ref name=b257>Benedetti (1999a, 257).</ref> * 1921: '''[[Alexander Pushkin]] musical evening'''. Opened on 14 July.<ref name=op40>Stanislavski and Rumyantsev (1998, 40–41).</ref> Presented at the [[Moscow Art Theatre|MAT]] for six performances.<ref name=b257/> * 1921: '''''[[Werther]]''''' by [[Jules Massenet]]. Opened on 2 August. * 1922: '''''[[Eugene Onegin (opera)|Eugene Onegin]]''''' by [[Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky]]. Opened on 15 June. Cast included Pavel Rumiantsev as Onegin.<ref name=b259>Benedetti (1999a, 259).</ref> Staged in the ballroom of Stanislavski's house on Leontievski Lane (which was known thereafter as the Onegin Room), with minimal set and no costumes or make-up. With a full orchestra the production transferred two years later to the Novi Teatr.<ref name=b259/> * 1926: '''''[[Il matrimonio segreto|The Secret Marriage]]''''' by [[Domenico Cimarosa]]. Opened on 5 April. * 1926: '''''[[The Tsar's Bride (opera)|The Tsar's Bride]]''''' by [[Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov]]. Opened on 28 November. * 1927: '''''[[La bohème]]''''' by [[Giacomo Puccini]]. Opened on 12 April. * 1928: '''''[[May Night]]''''' by [[Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov]]. Opened on 19 January. * 1928: '''''[[Boris Godunov (opera)|Boris Godunov]]''''' by [[Modest Mussorgsky]]. Opened on 5 March. * 1930: '''''[[The Queen of Spades (opera)|The Queen of Spades]]''''' by [[Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky]]. Opened on 26 February. * 1932: '''''[[The Golden Cockerel]]''''' by [[Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov]]. Opened on 4 May.
==Posthumous productions completed by others== * 1939: '''''[[Rigoletto]]''''' by [[Giuseppe Verdi]], production completed by [[Vsevolod Meyerhold]]. Opened on 10 March.<ref>Benedetti (1999a, 389) and Braun (1995, 293).</ref> * 1939: '''''[[Tartuffe]]''''' by [[Molière]], production completed by [[Mikhail Kedrov (director)|Mikhail Kedrov]]. Opened on 4 December. Cast included Kedrov as Tartuffe and Vasily Toporkov as Orgon.<ref>Solovyova (1999, 356).</ref>
==See also== * [[Moscow Art Theatre production of The Seagull|The MAT production of ''The Seagull'']] * [[Moscow Art Theatre production of Hamlet|The MAT production of ''Hamlet'']]
==Notes== {{reflist|3}}
==Sources== {{refbegin|30em}} * Benedetti, Jean, ed. and trans. 1991. ''The Moscow Art Theatre Letters.'' London: Routledge. {{ISBN|0-87830-084-8}}. * Benedetti, Jean. 1999a. ''Stanislavski: His Life and Art''. Revised edition. Original edition published in 1988. London: Methuen. {{ISBN|0-413-52520-1}}. * Benedetti, Jean. 1999b. "Stanislavsky and the Moscow Art Theatre, 1898–1938". In Leach and Borovsky (1999, 254–277). * Braun, Edward. 1982. ''The Director and the Stage: From Naturalism to Grotowski.'' London: Methuen. {{ISBN|0-413-46300-1}}. * Braun, Edward. 1988. Introduction. In ''Plays: 1''. By [[Maxim Gorky]]. Methuen World Classics ser. London: Methuen. xv-xxxii. {{ISBN|0-413-18110-3}}. * Braun, Edward. 1995. ''Meyerhold: A Revolution in Theatre.'' Rev. 2nd ed. London: Methuen. {{ISBN|0-413-72730-0}}. * Carnicke, Sharon M. 1998. ''Stanislavsky in Focus''. Russian Theatre Archive Ser. London: Harwood Academic Publishers. {{ISBN|90-5755-070-9}}. * Gauss, Rebecca B. 1999. ''Lear's Daughters: The Studios of the Moscow Art Theatre 1905–1927''. American University Studies ser. 26 Theatre Arts, vol. 29. New York: Peter Lang. {{ISBN|0-8204-4155-4}}. * Gottlieb, Vera, ed. and trans. 2005. ''Anton Chekhov at the Moscow Art Theatre: Archive Illustrations of the Original Productions.'' London: Routledge. {{ISBN|0-415-34440-9}}. Reproduction of original journal ed. Nikolai Efros, published in Moscow, 1914. * Innes, Christopher, ed. 2000. ''A Sourcebook on Naturalist Theatre''. London and New York: Routledge. {{ISBN|0-415-15229-1}}. * Leach, Robert. 1989. ''Vsevolod Meyerhold.'' Directors in Perspective ser. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. {{ISBN|0-521-31843-2}}. * Leach, Robert. 2004. ''Makers of Modern Theatre: An Introduction''. London: Routledge. {{ISBN|0-415-31241-8}}. * Leach, Robert, and Victor Borovsky, eds. 1999. ''A History of Russian Theatre.'' Cambridge: Cambridge UP. {{ISBN|0-521-43220-0}}. * [[David Magarshack|Magarshack, David]]. 1950. ''Stanislavsky: A Life.'' London and Boston: Faber, 1986. {{ISBN|0-571-13791-1}}. * Marker, Frederick J., and Lise-Lone Marker. 1989. ''Ibsen's Lively Art: A Performance Study of the Major Plays.'' Cambridge: Cambridge UP. {{ISBN|0-521-61924-6}}. * Marsh, Cynthia, ed. 1993. ''File on Gorky.'' Writer-Files ser. London: Methuen. {{ISBN|978-0-413-65060-3}}. * Rudnitsky, Konstantin. 1988. ''Russian and Soviet Theatre: Tradition and the Avant-Garde''. Trans. Roxane Permar. Ed. Lesley Milne. London: Thames and Hudson. Rpt. as ''Russian and Soviet Theater, 1905–1932''. New York: Abrams. {{ISBN|0-500-28195-5}}. * Senelick, Laurence, ed. and trans. 2013. ''Stanislavsky—A Life in Letters: The Missionary in the Theatre.'' Abingdon, Oxon: Routledge. {{ISBN|1-136-34341-5}}. * Solovyova, Inna. 1999. "The Theatre and Socialist Realism, 1929–1953." Trans. Jean Benedetti. In Leach and Borovsky (1999, 325–357). * Stanislavski, Constantin, and Pavel Rumyantsev. 1975. ''Stanislavski on Opera.'' Trans. Elizabeth Reynolds Hapgood. London: Routledge, 1998. {{ISBN|0-87830-552-1}}. * [[Yevgeny Vakhtangov|Vakhtangov, Evgeny]]. 1982. ''Evgeny Vakhtangov''. Compiled by Lyubov Vendrovskaya and Galina Kaptereva. Trans. Doris Bradbury. Moscow: Progress. * Worrall, Nick. 1996. ''The Moscow Art Theatre.'' Theatre Production Studies ser. London and NY: Routledge. {{ISBN|0-415-05598-9}}. {{refend}}
{{Stanislavski system}}

revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=October 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{Infobox theatre | name = Liverpool Playhouse | image = Playhouse Theatre, Liverpool 2018-2.jpg | image_size = 250 | image_alt = | caption = Liverpool Playhouse | image_map = | map_caption = | pushpin_map = Merseyside | pushpin_map_caption= Location in Merseyside | address = [[Williamson Square]] | city = [[Liverpool]] | country = England | designation = [[listed building|Listed Building Grade II*]] | coordinates = {{coord|53.4064|-2.9826|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | architect = Edward Davies, Harry Percival,
Stanley Adshead,
Hall, O'Donahue and Wilson | owner = Liverpool and Merseyside Theatres Trust | tenant = | operator = Liverpool and Merseyside Theatres Trust | capacity = | type = Theatre | opened = 1866 | reopened = | yearsactive = | rebuilt = | closed = | demolished = | othernames = Star Music Hall,
Star Theatre of Varieties,
Liverpool Repertory Theatre | production = | currentuse = | website = [http://www.everymanplayhouse.com/playhouse] }} The '''Liverpool Playhouse''' is a theatre in [[Williamson Square]] in the city of [[Liverpool]], England. It originated in 1866 as a [[music hall]], and in 1911 developed into a [[repertory]] theatre. As such it nurtured the early careers of many actors and actresses, some of whom went on to achieve national and international reputations. Architectural changes have been made to the building over the years, the latest being in 1968 when a modern-style extension was added to the north of the theatre. In 1999 a trust was formed, joining the management of the Playhouse with that of the [[Everyman Theatre, Liverpool|Everyman Theatre]]. ==History== The present theatre on the site was designed by Edward Davies, and opened in 1866. It replaced an earlier theatre called the Star Concert Hall. The present theatre was originally named the Star Music Hall.{{Citation | url = http://www.arthurlloyd.co.uk/Liverpool/PlayhouseTheatreLiverpool.htm| title = Playhouse Theatre, Williamson Square, Liverpool F.C.| accessdate = 14 August 2011| publisher = Matthew Lloyd}} In 1895 its name was changed to the Star Theatre of Varieties. The theatre was improved in 1898 by Harry Percival with a new auditorium and foyer, and electricity was installed. In 1911 the Liverpool Repertory Theatre Limited was established, with [[Basil Dean]] as its "controller and producer". The company could not afford to build a new theatre, and bought the Star Theatre for £28,000 {{Inflation|UK|28000|1911|r=-4|fmt=eq|cursign=£}}).{{Inflation-fn|UK|df=y}} This made it the first [[repertory]] in Britain to own the [[Freehold (law)|freehold]] of a theatre. The company spent a further £4,000 ({{Inflation|UK|4000|1911|r=-4|fmt=eq|cursign=£}}) on redesigning and modernising the theatre.{{Citation| last = Iles| first = Paul| title = Green Room versus Board Room: Liverpool Playhouse and Business Modelling for Resident Theatres| publisher = The Laughing Audience| url = http://www.laughingaudience.co.uk/business_models.html| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090304170514/http://www.laughingaudience.co.uk/business_models.html| dead-url = yes| archive-date = 4 March 2009| accessdate = 14 August 2011}} The auditorium and the basement foyer were redesigned by Stanley Adshead, the Professor of Civic Design at the Liverpool School of Architecture.{{Citation | last =Pollard| first =Richard | last2 = Pevsner | first2 = Nikolaus | author2-link =Nikolaus Pevsner| series= The Buildings of England|title =Lancashire: Liverpool and the South-West | publisher =[[Yale University Press]] | year =2006 | location =New Haven and London | page = 301| isbn =0-300-10910-5 }} The theatre was for many years managed by [[Maud Carpenter]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sarsfieldmemorialsliverpool.co.uk/memorial-maud-farrington-nee-carpenter/|title=Memorial to Maud Farrington nee Carpenter|publisher=Sarsfieldmemorialsliverpool.co.uk|accessdate=8 March 2016}} The theatre was renamed the Liverpool Repertory Theatre, and in 1916 renamed again, as the Liverpool Playhouse. Minor structural alterations were made to the theatre in 1961 and in 1966. In 1968 a modern-style extension was added to the north of the theatre to accommodate new foyers, bars, dressing rooms and a workshop. In the 1990s the theatre company went into liquidation. In 1999 the Liverpool and Merseyside Theatres Trust Limited was established as a charity, and the theatre re-opened.{{Citation | url = http://www.charitycommission.gov.uk/Showcharity/RegisterOfCharities/CharityWithPartB.aspx?RegisteredCharityNumber=1081229&SubsidiaryNumber=0| title = Liverpool and Merseyside Theatres Trust Ltd| accessdate = 14 August 2011| publisher = [[Charity Commission]]}} It is managed jointly with the [[Everyman Theatre, Liverpool|Everyman Theatre]] by [[Liverpool City Council]].{{Citation | last = Pye| first = Ken| year = 2011| title = Discover Liverpool| publication-place = Liverpool| publisher = Trinity Mirror Media| page = 66| isbn = 978-1-906802-90-5}} ==Artistes== As a repertory company, the theatre has been involved in the careers of actors and actresses who have later achieved wide fame. [[Noël Coward]] and [[Gertrude Lawrence]] worked with the company as child actors. Other artistes who gained experience at the theatre include [[Robert Donat]], [[Lilian Braithwaite]], [[Cecil Parker]], [[John Gregson]], [[Clive Brook]], [[C. Aubrey Smith]], [[Richard Burton]], [[Michael Redgrave]], [[Diana Wynyard]], [[Rex Harrison]], [[Patricia Routledge]], [[Anthony Hopkins]], and [[Richard Briers]]. ==Architecture== ===Older section=== The exterior of the older part of the theatre is [[stucco]]ed, and it has a [[slate]] roof. Its entrance front faces Williamson Square. It has seven [[bay (architecture)|bays]] and is in three storeys. The central three bays project forward and are surmounted by a broken [[pediment]]. On the ground floor the central bays contain three entrances, separated by pillars, which lead to a recessed porch. Over each entrance is an [[architrave]] containing a [[fanlight]]. The lateral bays contain two round-headed and one flat-headed entrance on each side, over which are three blind round windows. In the middle storey, the bays are separated by [[pilaster]]s. The three central bays each have a [[baluster|balustrade]] and a window with a [[Tympanum (architecture)|tympanum]] containing a roundel. Each of the three lateral bays contains a window with a [[cornice]], and a round window above it. Along the top storey are [[Oculus|oculi]] between panelled pilasters. On the summit of each of the two lateral bays is a [[cupola]] on a short [[Tuscan order|Tuscan]] [[colonnade]]. Inside the older part of the theatre are two balconies supported by [[cast iron]] columns. The interior is decorated in [[Greek Revival architecture|Greek Revival]] style.{{NHLE |num= 1218642|desc= Playhouse Theatre, Liverpool F.C.|accessdate= 20 August 2013|mode=cs2|ps=none}} ===Newer section=== The newer section is constructed in concrete, and largely faced by glass. On the ground floor are entrance doors. Above this, the building is based around three cylinders. The largest of these starts at the first floor and rises through two storeys. It is [[cantilever]]ed from a central column. To the left is a smaller cylinder, cantilevered from a separate column, interlocking with the larger cylinder. Inside the whole is a hollow column containing the stairs. ===Assessment and critique=== The theatre is recorded in the [[National Heritage List for England]] as a designated Grade II* [[Listed building#England and Wales|listed building]], having been designated on 14 March 1975. In its description, the list quotes the ''[[Architects' Journal]]'' of 1968 which says of the older section that it is "significant as an early and rare work by one of the pioneers of the Liverpool School of Architecture, in the Grecian style favoured by the school at that date", and of the newer section that it is "a brilliant concept, joyously realised, which exploits asymmetrical volumes and ever varying spaces yet achieves unity and also balance with the adjoining [[Victorian architecture|Victorian]] façade".{{Citation | publication-date = 4 December 1968| title = | periodical = [[Architects' Journal]]| page = 1327}} In the ''[[Pevsner Architectural Guides|Buildings of England]]'' series the architectural historians Richard Pollard and [[Nikolaus Pevsner]] say of the newer section that it is "a spectacular composition" which creates an atmosphere of excitement and anticipation, exactly right for a theatre foyer". ==See also== {{Portal|Merseyside}} *[[Architecture of Liverpool]] ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Playhouse Theatre, Liverpool}} *[http://www.everymanplayhouse.com Official website of the Playhouse and Everyman theatres] {{Liverpool B&S}} [[Category:Grade II* listed buildings in Liverpool]] [[Category:Theatres in Liverpool]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Liverpool]] [[Category:Theatres completed in 1866]] [[Category:Producing theatres in England]] [[Category:1866 establishments in England]]

{{Infobox company | name = Maped SAS | logo = Maped logo.png | logo_size = 200px | caption = | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | traded_as = | genre = | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = {{start date and age|1947}}[http://www.maped.com/en/produits.html#contenu=historique&langue=en History of Maped - official site] | founder = | defunct = | location_city = [[Annecy]] | location_country = [[France]] | location = | locations = | area_served = Worldwide [http://www.maped.com/en/produits.html#contenu=monde&langue=en Maped around the World] | key_people = Jacques Lacroix, CEO. | industry = [[Stationery]] | products = [[Writing instrument]]s | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = [http://www.maped.com/en/produits.html#contenu=accueil&langue=en www.maped.com] | footnotes = | intl = }} '''Maped''' ('''M'''anufacture d''''A'''rticles de '''P'''recision '''E'''t de '''D'''essin) is a family run [[France|French]] based manufacturer of scholastic and office [[stationery]]. With subsidiaries in 9 countries, it has expanded worldwide to over 125 countries. == History == Maped was founded in 1947 in [[Annecy]], with its first products being brass compasses, in 1992 it proceeded to take over Mallatt, a company specializing in the manufacture of erasers, thus diversifying its range. After setting up a subsidiary in China in 1993, Maped began to diversify even more, and spread worldwide over the following years. In 2003 it aired its first TV commercial in France and in 2006 it took over the German office stationery supplier Halit and JFP Graphos of France. In 2012 they also took over the English family run business of Helix, which is now called Maped Helix. ==Products== Maped produces a wide range of products, mainly writing instruments such as [[fountain pens]], [[pen]]s and [[marker pen|marker]]s.[http://www.maped.com/en/produits.html#contenu=catalogue&langue=en&uni_id=5 Maped catalog as of October, 2011]
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" ! Category !! Products Lines |- |align=center| Writing || [[ballpoint pen]]s, [[mechanical pencil]]s |- |align=center| School || [[Compass]]es, [[eraser]]s, [[pencil sharpener]]s,
[[coloured pencil]]s, [[scissors]], [[marker pen]]s, [[ruler]]s, [[set square]]s |- |align=center| Office || Scissors, [[Utility knife|cutter]]s, [[paper cutter]]s,
[[stapler]]s, [[punch (tool)|punche]]s, [[paper clip|clip]]s |- |align=center| Craftwork || Cutters, [[architect's scale]]s, angle templates,
craft scissors, [[hole punch]]es |- |- |}
==[[Heller SA|Heller Joustra]]== On 11 March , 2016 the Commercial Court of Argentan approved the acquisition of Heller-Joustra ([[Heller SA]]) by Maped. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.maped.com/en/produits.html#contenu=accueil&langue=en Official website] {{en icon}} {{Pen manufacturers}} [[Category:Printing companies of France]] [[Category:French brands]] [[Category:Design companies established in 1947]] [[Category:1947 establishments in France]] {{France-company-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=December 2015}}
{{Use American English|date=July 2012}} The '''Midlands Music Awards''' (MMAs) are an annual award ceremony, run by the Midlands Music Organization, where accolades are presented to members of [[Zimbabwe]]'s music industry who come from the [[Midlands Province]] of [[Zimbabwe]]. Winners receive a statuette. The event was established in June 2014. The ceremony is held in June every year and contenders are judged on performances made in the previous year. The show is held at the Midlands Hotel in the '''capital''' of the '''province''' [[Gweru]] and broadcast on [[Zimbabwe Broadcasting Corporation]] - Zbc TV. The ceremony features live performances by some of the nominees.
==Awards== MMAs grouped into a number of categories which are representative of [[Zimbabwe]]'s varying popular musical genres. The award is made up of 60% from the panel of judges (adjudicators) and the other 40% comes from the public through voting platforms such as [[sms]] among others.
===List of Midlands Music Awards Categories=== * Best Male Artist * Best Female Artist * Newcomer of the Year * Best [[Hip hop]] * Best [[Rnb]] and [[Soul music]] * Best [[Gospel music]] * Best Sungura music * Best Music Video of the Year * Best Jazz music * Best Afropop music * Radio Dj/Personality of the Year * Best Club Dj * Best Traditional Group * Best Dance Group * Best House music * Best Collaboration of the Year * Best Reggae/Chigiyo music * Best Producer of the Year * Best Music Album of the Year * [[Lifetime Achievement Award]]
==Inaugural Midlands Music Awards (2014)== The Inaugural MMAs were held on 28 June 2014<ref>{{cite web | title =Midlands Music Awards on tonight | url = https://www.dailynews.co.zw/articles/2014/06/28/midlands-music-awards-on-tonight | date = 2014-06-28}}</ref> in the '''capital''' of the '''province''' [[Gweru]] with the following awards issued: * Best Dancehall - Legion * Newcomer of the Year - Slykiezle * Best [[Hip hop]] - [[L kat]] * Best [[Rnb]] and [[Soul music]] Male - Goodchild * Best [[Rnb]] and [[Soul music]] Female - Marcyjay * Best [[Gospel music]] - Trymo Mutodza * Best Sungura music - Peter Moyo * Best Music Video of the Year - Goodchild for ''Arikundinyepera'' * Best Jazz music (Male) - Jazzy Jazz * Best Jazz music (Female) - Shingi Mangoma * Radio Dj/Personality of the Year - Dj Chilli ([[Zimbabwe Broadcasting Corporation]]'s - Power FM) * Best Club Dj - Dj Stavo * Best House music - Mr Khoax * Best Collaboration of the Year - ''Tisanyadzise'' by [[L kat]] featuring Goodchild * Best Reggae/Chigiyo music - Bantuman I * Best Producer of the Year - Prince ''Oskid'' Tapfuma * Best Music Album of the Year - [[L kat]] for ''Goodlife'' * [[Lifetime Achievement Award]] - [[Tongai Moyo]] and Bob Nyabinde * Best Promoter of the Year - Mavis Koslek ''Image Modelling Agency''
==2nd Annual Midlands Music Awards (2015)== The 2nd Annual MMAs were held on 29 June 2015<ref>{{cite web | title =All set for Midlands Music Awards | url = http://www.herald.co.zw/all-set-for-midlands-music-awards/ | date = 2015-06-30}}</ref> in the '''capital''' of the '''province''' [[Gweru]] with the following awards issued: * Best Dancehall - Lewaz Skattah for ''Quarter 2 Twelve'' * Newcomer of the Year - Nybal for ''True Gospel'' * Best [[Hip hop]] - [[L kat]] for ''The Golden Episode - EP'' * Best [[Rnb]] and [[Soul music]] - Valentyne for ''I'm Not Afraid'' * Best [[Gospel music]] - Mathias Mhere for ''Glory to Glory'' * Best Music Video of the Year - Ur Highness for ''Incompatible'' * Best Jazz music - Tasarina for ''Zvakarongeka'' * Best Afropop music - Soul Afrika for ''Singles Collection'' * Best Club Dj - Dj Brian and Dj Masty * Best House music - Shingi Mangoma for ''Handikusiye'' * Best Collaboration of the Year - Goodchild and Dj Neo for ''Nakuyewa'' * Best Reggae/Chigiyo music - Joe Wailer for ''Beautiful Zimbabwe'' * Best Producer of the Year - Prince ''Oskid'' Tapfuma * Best Music Album of the Year - Mathias Mhere for ''Glory to Glory'' * [[Lifetime Achievement Award]] - Ismael Petker of Mahogany Sounds
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Zimbabwean music]] [[Category:Music awards]] [[Category:Midlands Province]] [[Category:2014 music awards]] [[Category:2015 music awards]]

{{Infobox NRHP |name = Mt. Horeb Opera Block |image = Mt. Horeb Opera Block.jpg |caption = Mt. Horeb Opera Block |location = 109-117 E. Main St.
[[Mount Horeb, Wisconsin]] |built = 1895 |architect = Gordon and Paunack |architecture = [[Queen Anne style architecture in the United States|Queen Anne]]/[[Romanesque architecture|Romanesque]] |refnum = 89000068 |added = February 23, 1989 }} The '''Mt. Horeb Opera Block''' is located in [[Mount Horeb, Wisconsin]]. It was added to the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 1989.{{cite web|url=http://landmarkhunter.com/137635-mt-horeb-opera-block/|title=Mt. Horeb Opera Block|publisher=Landmark Hunter.com|accessdate=2012-02-07}} ==History== The building has hosted theatrical troupes, dances and political rallies. It began showing movies after 1907.{{cite web|url=http://www.wisconsinhistory.org/hp/register/viewSummary.asp?refnum=89000068|title=Mt. Horeb Opera Block|publisher=Wisconsin Historical Society|accessdate=2012-02-07}} Other events that have taken place there include high school graduation ceremonies, basketball games and speeches by the [[Woman's Christian Temperance Union]]. In 1917, when the local high school was destroyed in a fire, classes were held at the Mt. Horeb Opera Block while the new high school was being constructed. ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Buildings and structures in Dane County, Wisconsin]] [[Category:Opera houses in Wisconsin]] [[Category:Cinemas and movie theaters in Wisconsin]] [[Category:Former cinemas in the United States]] [[Category:Queen Anne architecture in Wisconsin]] [[Category:Romanesque Revival architecture in Wisconsin]] [[Category:Music venues completed in 1895]] [[Category:Theatres completed in 1895]] [[Category:National Register of Historic Places in Dane County, Wisconsin]] [[Category:Opera houses on the National Register of Historic Places in Wisconsin]] [[Category:1895 establishments in Wisconsin]]

{{Infobox book | name = Never Cry Wolf | title_orig = | translator = | image = Never Cry Wolf (book).jpg | caption = First edition | author = [[Farley Mowat]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = Canada | language = English | series = | subject = [[Autobiography]] | publisher = [[McClelland and Stewart]] | release_date = 1963 | english_release_date = | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover|hard]] & [[paperback]]) | pages = 256 pp | isbn = 0-316-88179-1 | oclc= 48027680 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Never Cry Wolf''''' is an account of the author’s experience observing wolves in subarctic Canada<ref>{{cite web|url=http://people.rit.edu/~kecncp/Courses/Materials/NeverCryWolf/NCW-book/Mini-Guide.Mowat.pdf|title=Never Cry Wolf|work=People.rit.edu}}</ref> by [[Farley Mowat]], first published in 1963 by [[McClelland and Stewart]]. It was adapted into a [[Never Cry Wolf (film)|film of the same name]] in 1983. It has been credited for dramatically changing the public image of the [[wolf]] to a more positive one.
==Form of the book== In the book, Mowat describes his experiences in a first-person narrative that sheds light on his research into the nature of the [[Arctic wolf]].
In 1948–1949, the Dominion Wildlife Service assigns the author to investigate the cause of declining [[caribou]] populations and determine whether wolves are to blame for the shortage. Upon finding his quarry near [[Nueltin Lake]], Mowat discovers that rather than being wanton killers of caribou, the wolves subsist quite heavily on small mammals such as rodents and hares, "even choosing them over caribou when available."
==Conclusions== He concludes: "We have doomed the wolf not for what it is but for what we deliberately and mistakenly perceive it to be: the mythologized epitome of a savage, ruthless killer—which is, in reality, not more than the reflected image of ourselves. We have made it the scapewolf for our own sins." Mowat writes to expose the onslaught of [[wolfers (hunting)|wolfers]] and government exterminators who are out to erase the wolves from the Arctic.
==Points and claims== Mowat's book says that: * The main reason for declining population of caribou is human hunters from civilization. * Wolves that hunt a large herd animal would rather attack weaker, injured, or older animals, which helps rid the herd of members that slow its migration. * Arctic wolves usually prey on Arctic ox, caribou, smaller mammals, and rodents—but since they rely on stamina instead of speed, it would be logical for the wolves to choose smaller prey instead of large animals like caribou, which are faster and stronger, and therefore a more formidable target. One of these animals may include mice. * A lone Arctic wolf has a better chance of killing small prey by running alongside it and attacking its neck. The wolf would be at a disadvantage if it attacked large prey from behind, because the animal's powerful hind legs could injure the wolf. However, a group of wolves may successfully attack large prey from a number of positions. * Since Arctic wolves often travel in a group, their best strategy is not to kill surplus prey, since the whole group can sate themselves on one or two large animals. There are, however, exceptions to this. * There are many local Eskimos, the majority of whom are traders. * The Eskimos can interpret wolves' howls. They can tell things such as whether a herd or a human is passing through the wolves' territory, the direction of travel, and more.
==Reception== [[Barry Lopez]] in his 1978 work ''Of Wolves and Men'' called the book a dated, but still good introduction to wolf behaviour.<ref name="Lopez">{{cite book | author = Lopez, Barry | title = Of wolves and men | year = 1978 | pages = 320 | isbn = 0-7432-4936-4}}</ref>
In a 2001 article of ''The Canadian Historical Review'' entitled ''Never Cry Wolf: Science, Sentiment, and the Literary Rehabilitation of Canis Lupus'', Karen Jones lauded the work as "an important chapter in the history of Canadian environmentalism";<ref name="Jones">Karen Jones, ''Never Cry Wolf: Science, Sentiment, and the Literary Rehabilitation of Canis Lupus'', The Canadian Historical Review vol.84 (2001)</ref>
{{Quotation|The deluge of letters received by the Canadian Wildlife Service from concerned citizens opposing the killing of wolves testifies to the growing significance of literature as a protest medium. Modern Canadians roused to defend a species that their predecessors sought to eradicate. By the 1960s the wolf had made the transition from the beast of waste and desolation (in the words of [[Theodore Roosevelt]]) to a conservationist cause celebre....''Never Cry Wolf'' played a key role in fostering that change.|Karen Jones, "Never Cry Wolf: Science, Sentiment, and the Literary Rehabilitation of Canis Lupus", ''The Canadian Historical Review'' vol.84 (2001)}}
At the time it was published, Mowat's book received criticism, often politically-motivated, about the veracity of his work and its conclusions. Canadian Wildlife Service official Alexander William Francis Banfield, who supervised Mowat's field work, characterised the book as "semi-fictional", and accused Mowat of blatantly lying about his expedition. He pointed out that contrary to what is written in the book, Mowat was part of an expedition of three biologists, and was never alone. Banfield also pointed out that a lot of what was written in ''Never Cry Wolf'' was not derived from Mowat's first hand observations, but were plagiarised from Banfield's own works, as well as from [[Adolph Murie]]'s ''The Wolves of Mount McKinley''.<ref name="Banfield">A.W.F Banfield, Review, "Never Cry Wolf", ''Canadian Field Naturalist'' 78, (January–March 1964): 52–54</ref> In a 1964 article published in the ''Canadian Field-Naturalist'', he compared Mowat's 1963 bestseller to [[Little Red Riding Hood]], claiming that, "I hope that readers of ''Never Cry Wolf'' will realize that both stories have about the same factual content."<ref name="Banfield" />
In the May 1996 issue of ''[[Saturday Night (magazine)|Saturday Night]]'', John Goddard wrote a heavily researched article entitled ''A Real Whopper'', in which he poked many holes in Mowat's claim that the book was non-fictional. He wrote:
{{Quotation|"As for the authenticity of his wolf story, he virtually abandoned his wolf-den observations after less than four weeks."|John Goddard, ''A Real Whopper'' from ''Saturday Night'' May 1996}}
Mowat excoriated Goddard's article as, "...bullshit, pure and simple... this guy’s got as many facts wrong as there are flies on a toad that’s roadkill.".<ref name="Burghes">{{cite web|last=Burgess |first=Steve |date=1999-05-11 |url=http://www.salon.com/people/bc/1999/05/11/mowat/index1.html |title=Northern exposure |publisher=Salon |accessdate=2006-03-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060111000538/http://www.salon.com/people/bc/1999/05/11/mowat/index1.html |archivedate=2006-01-11 |df= }}</ref> Journalist [[Val Ross]] of ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' agreed that "Mowat, more passionate polemicist than rigorous reporter, painted federal bureaucrats in darker colours than many deserved," but that Goddard's piece erred in the same way against Mowat.<ref name="Ross">{{cite web|last=Ross|first=Val|year=1996|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/a-smile-for-the-ages-a-legacy-in-words/article17981307/?page=all|title=A smile for the ages, a legacy in words|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|accessdate=2008-09-17}}</ref>
Although a claim that Mowat makes was that he interacted closely with a wolf pack alone in order to study them, the first wildlife biologist to successfully use the method of [[habituation]] to study and follow wild wolf packs in close proximity was fellow CWS scientist and International Wolf Specialist Group Canadian representative [[Ludwig N. Carbyn|Dr. Lu Carbyn]], in a 1970s study in Jasper National Park. Although also pointing out ''Never Cry Wolf'''s fictional rather than factual nature, his remarks were less critical, calling Farley Mowat's book "Good fiction and good reading".<ref name="hol">Holubitsky, J. (1999) "Dancing with wolves: The man who dared to go amid the pack". ''Edmonton Journal.'' 5 September 1999.</ref>
In 2012, Mowat spoke to the ''[[Toronto Star]]'' about his self-acknowledged reputation as a storyteller: “For years I felt the Toronto media were out to bury me alive," referring to latter-day efforts in the literary community to reassess his work according to the standards of modern journalism as opposed to memoir. “That was never my game,” he said. “I took some pride in having it known that I never let facts get in the way of a good story. I was writing subjective non-fiction all along.”<ref>{{cite web|title=Farley Mowat, acclaimed Canadian author, dead at 92|author=Rinehart, Dianne|date=May 7, 2014|work=[[Toronto Star]]|url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/books/2014/05/07/farley_mowat_acclaimed_canadian_author_dead_at_92.html}}</ref>
== Impact == ''Never Cry Wolf'' was a commercial success in Canada. Shortly after its publication, the [[Canadian Wildlife Service]] received a deluge of letters from concerned citizens opposing the killing of wolves. Though generally well received by the public, Mowat's allusions of the Canadian Wildlife Service as an organisation set out to exterminate wolves was met with anger from Canadian biologists. CWS staff members argued that the agency had never demanded the extermination of the wolf, the wolf being recognized as an integral part of the northern ecosystem. They further countered that Mowat's remit had not been to find justifications for wolf extermination, but to investigate the relationship between wolves and caribou. The locals were actually hunting the caribou, for a sport and a food source.<ref name="Jones" />
As with Mowat's other books, ''Never Cry Wolf'' was translated into [[Russian language|Russian]] and published in the [[Soviet Union]].<ref name="Black">{{cite journal |last=Black |first=Joseph L. |year=1995 |issue=Summer 1995 |title=Canada in the Soviet mirror: English-Canadian literature in Soviet translation |journal=Journal of Canadian Studies |issn= 0021-9495 |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa3683/is_199507/ai_n8718950/ |accessdate=2009-06-28}}</ref> The book's message that wolves were harmless mouse-eaters became influential, leading to popular reaction against Soviet wolf-culling efforts.<ref name="Graves">{{cite book | author = Graves, Will | url = http://www.wolvesinrussia.com/ | title = Wolves in Russia: Anxiety throughout the ages | year = 2007 | pages = 222 | isbn = 1-55059-332-3 | access-date = 2008-08-18 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090802182158/http://www.wolvesinrussia.com/ | archive-date = 2009-08-02 | dead-url = yes | df = }}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist|2}}
[[Category:1963 books]] [[Category:Books by Farley Mowat]] [[Category:McClelland & Stewart books]] [[Category:Canadian non-fiction books]] [[Category:English-language books]] [[Category:Books adapted into films]] [[Category:Wolves in literature]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = Pop in Q | image = Pop In Q poster.jpeg | alt = | caption = Poster | film name = {{film name | kanji = ポッピンQ | romaji = PoppinQ}} | director = Naoki Miyahara | producer = | screenplay = Shūko Arai | story = [[Izumi Todo]] | starring = [[Asami Seto]]
[[Shiori Izawa]]
