{{Multiple issues| {{COI|date=March 2015}} {{Original research|date=March 2015}} {{Refimprove|date=March 2015}} }} {{Infobox company | name = William Morris Agency | logo = WMa Logojpg.png | industry = [[Talent agent|Talent and Literary Agencies]] | foundation = {{Start date and age|1898}}
in [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[United States]] | defunct = {{End date and age|2009|07}} | successor = [[William Morris Endeavor]] | location_city = [[Beverly Hills, California]] | location_country = [[United States]] | homepage = {{URL|http://wmeentertainment.com}} }} [[File:William Morris Monogram.jpg|thumb|William Morris Fireplace Screen with monogram]] The '''William Morris Agency''' ('''WMA''') was a Hollywood-based [[talent agency]]. It represented some of the best known 20th century entertainers in film, television, and music. During its 109 year tenure{{cite web|title=Company Overview of William Morris Endeavor Entertainment, LLC|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=872395|work = [[Bloomberg Businessweek]]|accessdate= May 27, 2012}} it came to be regarded as the "first great talent agency in show business".{{cite book |last=Cullen |first=Frank |date= |title=Vaudeville old & new: an encyclopedia of variety performances in America, Volume 1|url=https://books.google.co.kr/books?id=XFnfnKg6BcAC&pg=PA1020&lpg=PA1020&dq=William+Morris,+Vaudeville+Agent&source=bl&ots=5vrFnOvcwZ&sig=gRTUu6ORD7BLKacr3_Z6756jTxk&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiFk8rMy87KAhVhYKYKHe4tCAAQ6AEIUzAN#v=onepage&q=William%20Morris%2C%20Vaudeville%20Agent&f=false|location= |publisher=Routledge |page=1020 |isbn=}} In April 2009, WMA announced it would merge with the [[Endeavor Talent Agency]] to form [[William Morris Endeavor]] which owns Miss Universe.{{cite news | last = Littleton| first = Cynthia | title = WMA, Endeavor approve merger | date = 2009-04-27 | publisher = Variety | url = http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118002879}} == History == === Beginnings === In 1898, William Morris (born Zelman Moses), a German Jewish immigrant to the US, posted a cross-hatch trademark above an office door in New York City{{spaced ndash}} four "X's", representing a W superimposed on an M{{cite web |url= http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/william-morris-agency-inc-history/|title=William Morris Agency, Inc. History|last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website=fundinguniverse.com |publisher= |access-date= 29 January 2016 |quote=}}{{spaced ndash}} and went into business as '''William Morris, Vaudeville Agent'''. By the time WMA formally incorporated in New York State on January 31, 1918, Morris' son [[William Morris Jr.]] and an office boy named [[Abe Lastfogel|Abraham Lastfogel]], who, after becoming a talent agent in his own right, entered into a business partnership with Morris Sr. As silent film grew into widely viewed entertainment, Morris encouraged his clients to experiment in the new medium. Stars such as [[Charlie Chaplin]], [[Al Jolson]], the [[Marx Brothers]], and [[Mae West]] were all represented by the company. By 1930, Morris had turned over leadership of the agency to his son and Lastfogel. In 1932, five years after his retirement, William Morris, Sr. died from heart failure. By that time, the Agency had begun the process of relocating from [[Hollywood and Vine]] to Canon Drive in Beverly Hills.{{cite web|url=http://www.brokawcompany.com/pop-ups/read_cnn_profile.html|title= A Charmed Life, or a Thirty-Six Short Makes It Big |publisher=The Brokaw Company|accessdate= November 13, 2011}} === 1945 to 2000 === [[File:GeraldFord William Morris Ford B1712 NLGRF photo contact sheet (1976-10-01)(Gerald Ford Library) (1).jpg|thumb|right|President [[Gerald Ford]] (right) meets in the Oval Office with a representative of the William Morris Agency to discuss advertising for his [[United States presidential election, 1976|1976]] campaign]] The William Morris Agency attained further industry dominance with the December 1949 acquisition of the Berg-Allenberg Agency. The senior agent in the motion picture department during the 1950s was [[Mike Zimring]].{{cite book|last=Weisbord|first=Merrily|title=Our future selves : love, life, sex, and aging|year=1991|publisher=North Atlantic Books|location=Berkeley, Calif.|isbn=978-1556431456|page=157}} By 1965, WMA's Music Department had emerged as an industry powerhouse, representing, among others, the [[Rolling Stones]], [[Sonny & Cher]], [[the Beach Boys]], and [[the Byrds]].{{citation needed|date=May 2012}} Less than 10 years later, in 1973, the Agency's newly established Nashville office provided another significant boost to the operations of William Morris, extending the Agency's reach into [[country music]] and beyond.{{Cite news| url =http://articles.latimes.com/2003/jan/16/business/fi-morris16 |title=Morris Targets Miami's Talent|author=Claudia Eller|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date =January 16, 2003}} In the early 1980s, WMA built the William Morris Plaza located at 150 El Camino Drive, directly across the street from its main building at 151 El Camino. In 1989, WMA acquired the [[Jim Halsey]] Company. In the early 1990s, WMA's Literary Department announced the largest book-to-screen deal ever inked when it sold the television rights for ''Scarlett'', the sequel to [[Margaret Mitchell]]'s ''[[Gone with the Wind (novel)|Gone With the Wind]]''. In 2000, WMA acquired The Writers Shop, which was owned by [[Jennifer Rudolph Walsh]].{{cite web|title=Jennifer Rudolph Walsh|url=http://leanin.org/stories/jennifer-rudolph-walsh/|accessdate=29 January 2016}} === Post-2000 === WMA's Miami Beach office opened in 2003, and WMA's [[Shanghai]] office opened in 2004. In 2007, the Agency expanded its London music operation, underscoring WMA's continued commitment to the international marketplace. Along with the addition of new personnel, the London office moved into the iconic Centre Point Tower. In 2003, a seismic shift occurred in the agency landscape when WMA's SVP and Theatre topper, George Lane, and fellow agent in charge of foreign rights, Michael Cardonick, left WMA to open Creative Artists Agency's New York City office and Theatrical Department.{{cite web|author=Robert Hofler |url=https://variety.com/2003/legit/markets-festivals/caa-opening-gotham-digs-1117881929/|title=CAA opening Gotham digs |publisher=Variety.com |date=2003-05-09 |accessdate=2015-04-27}} == 2009 merger with Endeavor == {{Main|William Morris Endeavor}} On April 27, 2009, WMA and the Endeavor Talent Agency announced that they were merging to form '''William Morris Endeavor'''.{{cite news | last = Finke | first = Nikki | title = Latest WMA-Endeavor Merger Update: Hollywood History In The Making Today: Endeavor And William Morris Vote Yes | date = 2009-04-27 | publisher = Deadline | url = http://www.deadline.com/2009/04/latest-wma-endeavor-merger-update/}} Endeavor executives [[Ari Emanuel]] and [[Patrick Whitesell]] were widely recognized as the architects of the deal and ultimately took the roles of WME Co-CEOs.{{cite news |url=http://www.laweekly.com/2009-05-28/news/william-morris-it-39-s-a-takeover-not-a-merger |title=It's A Takeover, Not A Merger |work= [[LA Weekly]] |date=May 28, 2009}} Following the official announcement of the merger, nearly 100 WMA employees and former board members were let go. One of those leaving was Jim Wiatt, who came to WMA in 1999 from International Creative Management, where he was Vice-Chairman, in 1999. He had joined WMA as President and Co-Chief Executive Officer, and had risen to Board Chairman.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/27/business/27steal.html?_r=1&adxnnl=1&adxnnlx=1262095435-iFfjNHxKyP6WEeNLa5Tssw |title=Layoffs in the William Morris-Endeavor Merger |author=Michael Cieply |date= December 26, 2009 |work= [[The New York Times]] }} After the merger, WMA permanently relocated its offices to the Endeavor building at 9601 Wilshire Boulevard in [[Beverly Hills, California]].{{cite news | last = Finke | first = Nikki | title = WME Will Stay In Endeavor Headquarters Instead Of Moving To New Morris Building | date = 2009-10-09 | publisher = Deadline | url = http://www.deadline.com/2009/10/wme-not-moving-to-new-building-instead-will-stay-in-endeavor-headquarters/}} == The WMA Agent Training Program == The WMA Agent Training Program, often referred to as the "mailroom", was established in the 1940s and is well known for its roster of successful alumni. Since the 1970s the program has been replicated at other talent agencies and studios, many of which were headed by former mailroom trainees. Once accepted, trainees rotate through different departments, starting with the mailroom, before becoming a full-time assistant or coordinator. WMA's longtime competitor, [[Creative Artists Agency]], was founded in 1975 by [[Michael Ovitz]], [[Ronald Meyer]], William Haber, [[Michael S. Rosenfeld]], and Rowland Perkins, all former WMA agent trainees.{{cite encyclopedia |last=Rose | first=Frank | title=The Agency | edition=First | year=1996 | publisher=Harper Business | location=New York | isbn=0887308074}}{{cite encyclopedia |last=Rensin | first=David | title=The Mailroom | edition=First | year=2003 | publisher=Ballantine Books | location=New York | isbn=0345442350}} [[David Geffen]] once called the WMA Agent Training Program "The Harvard School of Show Business – only better: no grades, no exams, a small stipend and great placement opportunities."{{cn|date=March 2017}} Graduates from the Training Program were perceived at a high level of prestige within the entertainment industry, because of the caliber of notable alums that have graduated from the program.{{rp|464}} Former Chairman [[Norman Brokaw]] became the first mailboy in the Beverly Hills Mailroom at age 15. The Agent Training program still exists today at William Morris Endeavor. It was famously documented in David Rensin's 2003 book, ''[[The Mailroom: Hollywood History from the Bottom Up]]''. == References == {{reflist|30em}} == Further reading == * {{cite book|title=Promises I Made My Mother|author=Haskell, Sam| ISBN =978-0345506559}} * {{cite book|title=[[The Mailroom: Hollywood History from the Bottom Up]]|author= Rensin, David| ISBN =978-0345442345}} * {{cite book|author=Rose, Frank |title=The Agency: William Morris and the Hidden History of Show Business|isbn=978-0887307492}} == External links == * {{official website|http://www.wmeentertainment.com}} [[Category:1898 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Companies based in Beverly Hills, California]] [[Category:Companies based in New York City]] [[Category:Entertainment companies of the United States]] [[Category:Talent and literary agencies]] [[Category:American companies established in 1898]]

{{more footnotes|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox artist | bgcolour = #6495ED | name = xurban_collective | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[New York City]], [[İzmir]], [[Istanbul]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[Turkey|Turkish]] | field = [[Conceptual art]] | training = | movement = | works = | patrons = | influenced by = | influenced = | awards = }} '''Xurban collective''' (stylized as '''xurban_collective''') is an international [[art collective]] founded in 2000. Core members of the group are Guven Incirlioglu and [[Hakan Topal]], whose transatlantic collaborations took the form of media projects and installations. xurban_collective's projects instigate the questioning, examination, and discussion of contemporary politics, theory, and ideology, utilizing documentary photography, video, new media and text. The collective focuses specifically on areas of regional conflicts, military spatial confinement, urban segregation and [[neoliberal]] exclusion strategies.<ref>[http://www.artfacts.net/en/artist/xurban-collective-33847/profile.html xurban_collective entry at Artfacts.net]</ref> In September 2012 xurban_collective members concluded their collaboration to focus on their personal projects, artistic research and production.
==Members== Guven Incirligioglu (1960) studied architecture; photography and art theory (Ph.D.) and has exhibited since the 1980s in group shows and has held one person exhibitions in New York, Ankara, Istanbul, Sarajevo, Sofia and other locations working mostly with photography, photo-mechanical materials and new media. Since 1990, he was a lecturer in art and design in various schools in Turkey, including Bilkent University, Ankara, and Istanbul Bilgi University and is currently a faculty member at Economy University's Faculty of Art and Design in Izmir.
[[Hakan Topal]] is an artist and scholar living and working in New York City. He is a graduate faculty at the School of Visual Arts’ Fine Arts Department and teaching at the New Media and Art + Design departments at SUNY’s Purchase College. Trained as a civil engineer (B.S.), he continued his studies in gender and women’s Studies (M.S.) and sociology (M.A.). He received his Ph.D. in sociology from the New School for Social Research, New York with a concentration of urban sociology and sociology of arts. His dissertation titled "Negotiating Urban Space: Contemporary Art Biennials, The Case of [[New Orleans]]". In 2010, he was the guest editor of the [[ArteEast]] Quarterly Journal’s Silence issue, finished a documentary film project on a major late 18th-century Austro-Bavarian sculptor, [[Franz Xaver Messerschmidt]], commissioned by Neue Galerie New York. Topal is working on an upcoming book project about the idea of collateral damage and condolence payments in globalized wars, supported by [[Prince Claus Fund]].
Over the last decade, xurban_collective collaborated numerous other cultural producers, including Ali Demirel, Mehmet Ali Üzelgün, Atif Akın, Elif Akşit, Akın Gülseren, Jillian McDonald, Bülent Öztürk and Mahir Yıldırım.
== Exhibitions == xurban_collective exhibited internationally including projects in institutions such as the 49th [[Venice Biennial]] (2001), the 8th International [[Istanbul Biennial]] (2003), PS1/[[MoMA]] (2005), Apexart (2004),<ref>[http://www.apexart.org/exhibitions/wright.htm The Future of the Reciprocal Readymade (The use-value of art) ]</ref> Exitart (2005) and [[ZKM]] – Center for Art and Media, Karlsruhe (2004). xurban_collective participated in the "Political/Minimal" show curated by Klaus Biesenbach (MoMA, New York).<ref>[http://www.frieze.com/shows/review/political_minimal Gritz, Anna. “Political/Minimal”, Frieze Magazine (January 2009)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140924050727/http://www.frieze.com/shows/review/political_minimal |date=September 24, 2014 }}</ref> Most recently, xurban_collective is exbitited at TBA21-Vienna (2010), The National Contemporary Art Museum, Athens (2010) and Arter-Istanbul (2011) and participated in ROUNDTABLE: The 9th [[Gwangju Biennale]], which took place September 7 – November 11, 2012 in Gwangju, Korea.

{{refimprove|date=September 2008}} "'''Young fogey'''" is a term humorously applied, in British context, to some younger-generation, rather buttoned-down{{Clarify|date=October 2017}} writers and journalists, such as [[Simon Heffer]], [[Charles Moore (journalist)|Charles Moore]] and, for a while, [[A. N. Wilson]]. The term is attributed to [[Alan Watkins]] writing in 1984 in ''[[The Spectator]]''.{{cn|date=October 2017}}
"Young [[wikt:fogey|fogey]]" is still used to describe [[Conservatism|conservative]] young men (aged approximately between 15 and 40) who [[vintage clothing|dress in a vintage style]] (usually that of the 1920s-1930s, also known as the "Brideshead" look (after the influence of the [[Evelyn Waugh]] novel ''[[Brideshead Revisited]]''). Young-fogeys tend towards erudite, conservative cultural pursuits, especically art and traditional architecture, rather than sports. The young-fogey style of dress also has some surface similarity with the American [[preppy]] style, but is endogenous to the [[United Kingdom]] and anglo-centric areas of the [[Commonwealth of Nations|British Commonwealth]] such as [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]].{{cn|date=April 2018}}
==History== The movement reached its peak in the 1980s with champions such as [[A.N. Wilson]], [[Gavin Stamp]] and [[John Martin Robinson]] and a relatively widespread following, but has declined since. Though generally a middle class phenomenon, it had a wider influence on fashions in the 1980s. Young-fogeys are rarely rich or upper class and sometimes make a style virtue of genteel poverty, especially when rescuing old houses.<ref>John Martin Robinson & Alexandra Artley, The New Georgian Handbook. Harpers, London, 1985</ref> They often combine a conservative cultural outlook with a distate of Conservative political activity. They find [[feminism]] perpexing but are often open to [[bisexuality]] with men; even firmly heterosexual youg-fogeys have [[homosocial]] tendencies.{{cn|date=November 2018}} Often religious, their conservative outlook extends to refuting progressive theology.
Today committed young-fogeys may found amongst students at Oxford, Cambridge, [[Durham University|Durham]], [[Edinburgh]] and [[St Andrews]] universities; and at some universities in the Commonwealth, notably the [[University of Melbourne]] and [[Sydney]].{{cn|date=November 2018}} Adherents tend to concentrate in some professions: in particular the [[antique]]s and art dealing, residential estate agency, conservative classical [[architecture]] practices and certain strata of the [[Roman Catholic]] and [[Anglican]] churches.{{cn|date=November 2018}} Strongholds of young fogeys include the [[Oxford University Conservative Association]]{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}} and [[Trinity College, Cambridge]],{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}} but they are also seen elsewhere.
==People== Irish broadcaster [[Ryan Tubridy]], who hosts ''[[The Late Late Show (Ireland)|The Late Late Show]]'', has described himself as a "young fogey".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.herald.ie/entertainment/around-town/i-wont-stay-on-late-late-show-forever-reveals-ryan-1992876.html|title=I won't stay on Late Late Show forever, reveals Ryan - Making plans: Tubridy doesn't see 'dream job' as his final TV gig|first=Caitlin|last=McBride|work=Evening Herald|publisher=Independent News & Media|date=30 December 2009}}</ref>
British [[Member of Parliament#United Kingdom|Member of Parliament]] [[Jacob Rees-Mogg]] was described as a "young fogey" after [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|his 2010 election to Westminster]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1293560/QUENTIN-LETTS-Young-fogey-whos-charmed-Lefties.html|title=Young fogey who's charmed the Lefties|first=Quentin|last=Letts|work=Daily Mail|publisher=Daily Mail and General Trust|date=9 July 2010}}</ref>
British writer, editor, and broadcaster [[Anthony Lejeune]] was described by ''[[The Times]]'' as: "always out of period, a misfit in the modern world for whom the term 'young fogey' might have been invented".<ref name=times>[https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/obituary-anthony-lejeune-p7vkl5hcb Anthony Lejeune.] ''The Times'', 26 March 2018. Retrieved 30 March 2018. {{subscription required}}</ref>
